“ with which Cicero acted on his discovery of his brother’s

treachery l He wrote to Caesar a letter (of which we still preserve the copy which he sent to Atticus3 Att. xi. 12, 2) completely absolving his brother from the suspicion of having instigated his own hostility against Caesar, or having urged him to fly to Greece, and begging the good offices of Caesar for a brother under the recent sense of whose baseness to him he must have been still smarting. It seems to me that this is an act of large nobleness and truly chivalrous feeling, quite startling when we remem- ber the times in which Cicero lived.
